title: Is it possible to have black hole inside a black hole? - Quora

There may also be circumstances where the galactic core is a formation with no firm boundaries, just a jumble of gravity, energy, and matter be pulled in all directions by the gravitational forces surrounding it. They conclude that the " CALM EYE " they think lies at the core of Galaxies to be a " BLACK HOLE ". However, Galaxies are based on gravitation, and there is " NO " calm eye at their core. Back to the color of a Galaxy Core Star (s) - the color would be bright and probably white or close to it depending on it's composition, but not black. http://www.creationoftheuniverse.org/ For more info on how the process started.

Maybe, we can't adequately model what happens in a black hole so it's not really possible to answer. It also depends on what you mean by “inside a black hole”. I interpret that to mean the space beyond the event horizon, but the space just beyond the event horizon isn't really any different from the space just outside of the event horizon. Space gets weirder the further in you go and, when you get to the very centre, our models completely fail. That's what's meant by the term “singularity”, a failure of the mathematical models we use to describe the Universe, it's not an actual, physical thing. People, including me, will talk about the singularity as if it was a physical thing because most of us understand that it's shorthand for “the point at the centre of a black hole where our mathematical models of the Universe fail”. That the models fail in that regime suggest that they're incomplete and their results have diverged from reality at some point before the point they fail completely. It's sort of like how, if your car's engine suddenly seizes up and you skid to a stop, the problem with the engine actually existed long before it failed completely (there was likely a “check engine” light that you ignored). The models are not, however, completely wrong, in fact, they have been extensively tested and agree with reality as much as we've been able to determine so far.
